review: Most police/detective novels fall into one of two categories. The first is when neither the detective nor the reader knows who the killer is so we folMost police/detective novels fall into one of two categories. The first is when neither the detective nor the reader knows who the killer is so we follow the investigation together, through the inevitable dead ends and red herrings until the criminal is tracked down. The second is when the reader knows who the killer is and we watch the cat-and-mouse game between the dogged detective and the killer who isn't as smart as he thinks. (In both of these, the killer is almost never a woman, unless it's an Agatha Christie novel, for example; typical sexism…) In any case, this book falls into the second category.The plot pretty much falls into the typical pattern, a gloating killer who in this case actually begins to taunt the retired detective, Bill Hodges, to add a little sport to the “game.” Of course, through the usual dogged police, the detective begins to close the distance because we all know that right will triumph and these taunts will turn out to be valuable clues, whereupon the killer begins to become frustrated and starts to panic, etc., but what sets this novel apart is the quality of the writing; this is not the usual hack writing with a bunch of clever wordplay wrapped around incredibly lucky breaks and coincidences, this is Stephen King. It’s true that this isn’t the other-worldly horror of his earlier works but isn’t the horror of the world we live in, with serial killers and mass murderers, enough? This killer is twisted in other ways than we’re accustomed to, and we can see how he was formed, but the development and evolution are master works. Added to this, there are the twists that can’t be easily predicted and those we can see coming and hope to put the brakes to, that we hope we’re wrong about, that some miracle will save us from; sometimes we (or the characters) are saved and sometimes not, but we are hooked on the suspense. (Alfred Hitchcock, the “Master of Suspense” talked about this; instead of surprising us with an explosion, it’s better to tell us that there’s a bomb under the desk that’s about to explode and then have us wait, wait, wait, to see if it will be discovered in time.)I have to say that I didn’t like the end so much because I thought King put too much into it; less might have been more. I know that there are two more Bill Hodges novels and that one of the characters, Holly Gibney, has her own series, but I don’t feel either great rush to read them nor I not want to read them; if I come across them used, that’ll be great but if not, there are other books. I enjoyed this book and that’s enough for me....more

review: I had mixed feelings about this book. As a lifelong Yankee fan, I had to read everything about my childhood heroes, including all the ghost-written auI had mixed feelings about this book. As a lifelong Yankee fan, I had to read everything about my childhood heroes, including all the ghost-written autobiographies. Of course, at the time, I didn't realize that my heroes weren't actually sitting down with pen and paper, nor did I know they were completely sanitized, but I gobbled them up like M & M's.This of course changed when Jim Bouton wrote "Ball Four", which showed my idols to be more like flawed jocks, even more subject to human failings than most of us because their revered status protected them from scrutiny. (At the time, this was true, but now much less so with reporters scrambling for sordid details.) Joe Pepitone featured in Bouton's book and it was not at all flattering; the era when I first began following baseball with stars in my eyes - Mantle, Maris, etc. - showed my stars to be not all that shining. This brings me to Joe Pepitone, who died last year.The story here could be seen as a tragedy becuase the truth is that Joe Pepitone ruined his own career fighting his devils - trying to live up to his father, being Italian and playing in his hometown while really being a weak individual - but even in a time when the personal flaws of athletes were not always in the headlines, he was known as a pathological liar and whiner. Nothing was ever his fault, he'd been damaged by all this pressure, he couldn't help being the way he was and doing the things he did. The truth is that he wore on people so I saw this as a book which showed the real Joe Pepitone, a potentially great ballplayer who just never took responsibility, and why he was the way he was. I have no doubt that parts of this book are true - but which parts? When Pepitone came up to the Yankees, did the Mafia really offer to break Bill Skowron's legs so that Joe could be a starter at first base? Did he really smoke marijuana with Mickey Mantle before an exhibition game? Was he really a sex addict who would wander the streets all night looking for a woman - any woman - so that he could relax? The list goes on. (Not in the book but... in later years, he was in a car which was stopped by police and in which were found a substantial quantity of drugs; he denied knowledge, of course, but went to prison anyway.)There was no love lost between twice (New York and Houston) ex-teammates Bouton and Pepitone which may be why Bouton took such delight in his portrayal of Joe but I got the impression that he didn't have many friends anyway, or at least none that would do him any good. Bouton's portrayal of Pepitone as extremely vain was accurate, I think; he admiited to having two toupees, one for games and one for private life, and I remember he did commercials for The Hair Club for Men, a hairpiece company. This is probably one of the reasons I liked the book, thinking back on it in later years; I had a better sense of what the book said about Joe Pepitone, possibly without his even realizing it, his often false narrative revealing the failure within....more

review: The plot of this “roman á clef” will be immediately recognizable to anyone old enough to remember the tragic story of Mary Jo Kopechne, Senator Ted KeThe plot of this “roman á clef” will be immediately recognizable to anyone old enough to remember the tragic story of Mary Jo Kopechne, Senator Ted Kennedy and Chappaquiddick. Although the story takes place in a more modern era, post-Gulf War, the details (as we know or suppose them) remain the same: a bright young woman meets the senator at a party, they leave together for an encounter at a hotel, he drives off a bridge – possibly under the effects of alcohol – but escapes from the submerged car while she’s left behind, trapped, to slowly drown. It was a horrible story of a horrible death, that was never completely clarified but it pretty much ended any Presidential aspirations for the senator. Joyce Carol Oates was as caught up by the story as everyone else in the country at the time and this book is the result of it percolating in her brain over time.This novella confines itself to the accident, mostly in a series of flashbacks as the young woman, Elizabeth Anne (“Kelly”) Kelleher, is trapped in the car, waiting for the help which she is sure will arrive at any moment, as the water rises. She is a great admirer of “The Senator”, even having written a paper about him at university and articles about political views they have in common (i.e. the death penalty) for a left-wing newspaper, and is thrilled when he shows up at a party she’s been invited to by a friend from Brown University with whom she’s staying for the weekend. He makes romantic overtures to her, which she doesn’t exactly reject, and she leaves with him even though she isn’t sure she’s ready for that kind of relationship and in spite of her friend asking her not to leave but before leaving, he has one drink more then another, plus one more he carries with him in the car, they have to rush to make the ferry off the island, he makes a wrong turn, winding up on a disused road, and off the narrow bridge they go. All this is not told sequentially, but as a series of flashbacks as she recalls different parts of the narrative which has resulted in her being in this predicament. She imagines help arriving at any moment, “The Senator” swimming back to help her, the trip to the hospital in the ambulance, and all the while the water is rising. (We also find that the “Great Man” is not so great but more bent on survival; he also knows very well the political importance of covering one’s ass.)Joyce Carol Oates is never easy to read because she insists on making the reader uncomfortable as women suffer, usually at the hands of men who prove untrustworthy; she has said that the book was not specifically about Chappaquiddick but about a young woman putting her trust in an older man who violates that trust. The book was nominated for the Pulitzer Prize and has also been adapted into two separate operatic works – not surprising as the story is very powerful and has the traditional classical elements of that type of work. The audio version, read by Amanda Plummer, was considered by one New York Times critic to be “the best book-on-tape ever recorded. So, there’s a lot to recommend here. I always have mixed feelings about Oates because she makes me uneasy – it all feels so hopeless - but she’s someone who I come back to again and again. review: FreshwaterWow, this was one strange book! Even my wife and were divided on this as she hated it and finished out of pure stubbornness with gnas FreshwaterWow, this was one strange book! Even my wife and were divided on this as she hated it and finished out of pure stubbornness with gnashed teeth and smoke pouring out of her ears while I eventually entered the flow. It’s definitely ambitious and definitely not for everyone so if you haven’t read it yet, beware!The first thing that you have to remember is that in many cultures, mental illness is thought of as evil spirits invading the body and fighting for control – and that’s who narrates most of this story, evil spirits, sometimes separately and sometimes in conjunction. The body – “the Ada”, as they refer to her – is only a vessel, tossed to and fro at the whim of these spirits. These are rooted firmly in Nigerian Igbo tradition of “ogbanje”, reincarnating malevolent spirits who enter the body in order to cause it grief and pain,, similar to the Jewish “dybbuk” ; in the case of Ada, she has a split personality, one half shy, timid, conservative and the other a virago that seeks out and seduces men with an equally amoral and evil streak, only in order to destroy them. And by the same token, the aim of the spirits is to drive Ada to the point of suicide.It’s easy to dismiss this as superstitious nonsense but as I pointed out with the “dybbuk”, the idea of spirits exists in the Judeo-Christian tradition as well – if there’s a Holy Ghost, why not an unholy one? I live in a Catholic country (although the Evangelists are becoming more dominant) and I used to argue that if Jews and Christians can believe in a god they can’t see, and if one feels the spirit of Christ, why are other belief systems less valid? There is no shortage of books where people are “moved by the Spirit” so why discriminate because this is based in Igbo beliefs? Nor does the book dismiss Jesus as He makes an important appearance, albeit under a different name, and is regarded both respectfully and cynically by the other spirits.Furthermore, most mental illness is little understood; it usually has no physical manifestation so often we can’t REALLY say what causes it, and for that reason it’s often dismissed as a lack of character. (Ask anyone who’s suffered from clinical depression or addiction.) We live in an age where if you can’t produce some physical proof, like a tumor, people frequently aren’t willing to accept that there’s something there, so there’s no reason to dismiss out-of-hand “evil spirits.” Ada converses with her “ogbanje”, which brings to mind schizophrenia, and this spirit tries to dissuade and intercede against any sort of outside help, such as a psychiatrist or social worker, not unlike we’ve heard of schizophrenics abandoning treatment due to paranoia. For me, there were a lot of talking points in the book but I could also see why my wife didn’t like it; it’s often repetitive, depressing and plain frustrating to read but I found it worthwhile all the same. Recommendable for anyone willing to go with the flow.By the way, this is not your typical African book but so many Nigerian writers are out there now so there’s no reason to expect them to be alike. This author that doesn’t exactly fit into the Western mold: African and binary, which caused some problems with the committee for the Women’s Prize for Fiction since that’s obviously only for women and they didn’t realize that she didn’t identify as a woman and as one person put it, would a transgendered person who converted from being a male be considered? Not likely as there’s no category for “transgendered”. When “The Death of Vivek Oji” was submitted for inclusion, the committee asked for Emezi’s “sex as defined by law”, Emezi withdrew and accused the committee of being transphobic. So be it, Emezi is talented writer and all the rest is just noise....more

review: Sonja is, for lack of a better term, a nebbish. She spends all her time wondering why she can’t connect with people in quite the way she’d like but thSonja is, for lack of a better term, a nebbish. She spends all her time wondering why she can’t connect with people in quite the way she’d like but the truth is that she’s a square peg looking for her round hole while trying not to offend anyone and longing to make this connection while sunk in her own “inadequacies.” Most people describe this book as about loneliness but I also think it’s about a lack of courage, pure cowardice towards her own true self. Thoreau preached to march to our own drummer but Sonja just prefers to sit on the sidelines, tapping her toes and desperately hoping to find the beat.The main thread of the book is Sonja’s driving lessons where she “accepts” that she will never learn to drive, mainly because her first instructor, Jytte, more-or-less tells her so. She won’t let Sonja shift gears for herself and spends the entire lesson relating her family saga and chain-smoking, while yelling instructions at Sonja and belittling her student. Good strategy in a sense because Sonja, at 40 years old, is easily intimidated and having almost zero self-confidence. Instead of confronting Jytte, she quietly changes instructors to the owner, who seems to have an interest in Sonja beyond teaching her to drive. His approach gives Sonja more confidence in her driving but the added attention is unwanted. At the same time, Sonja can’t adjust to Copenhagen and desperately misses the countryside of Jutland, especially curling up with her mother, while wondering why her sister, Kate, won’t talk to her; to the reader, it becomes obvious that they are just on completely different wavelengths but Sonja frets about trying to reconnect to Kate’s while failing to understand that her own is perfectly good. There’s also the quirky New-Age masseuse that she goes to who offers good advice about standing up for herself while trying to get Sonja to try some of her own remedies, such as meditating in woods with other women.I spent this whole book waiting for something significant to happen; it’s a good thing it was short because the wait was in vain. This isn’t a bad book but I didn’t find it particularly good, either. It becomes obvious that Sonja will never confront anyone or accept who she is (except briefly at the end); Sonja doesn’t fight, she surrenders. This is not necessarily bad because we all have to accept sometimes that the fight is futile – e.g. irremediable relationships – but Sonja just whimpers, in my opinion. review: This is a fascinating book, not least because no one seems to be sure what it means, only that it is an allegory for SOMETHING. I couldn’t quite put mThis is a fascinating book, not least because no one seems to be sure what it means, only that it is an allegory for SOMETHING. I couldn’t quite put my finger on what exactly so I began to look at other opinions and no one seemed to be in agreement although all seemed to be focusing on more-or-less the same exact things. I later participated in a lecture on the book – which is why I read it in the first place, as the announced topic – and the esteemed author gave a lot of her own ideas. She was equally drawn to the same images but couldn’t be definite. And maybe that’s how literature ought to be, open to individual interpretation because not all things mean the same things to all people.The book begins with introductory premise from the first lines: a man in traffic stops his car because he’s suddenly and inexplicably been struck blind; one moment he can see and the next moment all he can see is a field of whiteness, blank like an unpainted canvas or a movie screen before the film starts. His wife takes him to a doctor, an ophthalmologist, and in the doctor’s office, we meet other patients who are waiting to be attended; the doctor can find no medical explanation for this sudden loss of sight and sends him home. From this point, it becomes bizarre because one-by-one, the man’s wife and everyone connected to this waiting room also becomes blind – except for the doctor’s wife. The easy answer is that somehow all of these people have “caught” something, but then this blindness begins to spread through the general population which understandably creates a panic. They are rounded up and put into camps, divided into two groups, those who are already blind and those who’ve been exposed to the blind. The doctor’s wife pretends to be blind as well in order to accompany her husband. From this point on, it becomes something of apocalyptic tale of horror with the ugliest sides of humanity exposed and the hopelessness felt by all those who have no answers to their situation, leaving them with no desire to go on. There has been a total breakdown of civilization.There are a couple of things that I took out of this. Many of today’s readers seized on the “epidemic” and compared it to the worldwide COVID crisis but I disagree. I compared it to the AIDS epidemic because we all knew what caused COVID even if they couldn’t (and possibly never will) pinpoint its precise origin; we knew it was a virus and it behaved like a virus so it was just a question of how to fight it. AIDS was a completely unknown virus that didn’t behave in the same form, particularly in its incubation period and I remember the sentiment of some at the time to round up all those who were affected or had been exposed in order to isolate them. I also remember black (and white) ministers who called it God’s judgement against homosexuality but when it began to hit the black community particularly hard, the conspiracy theory I heard was that this was a disease cooked up by the government to eliminate black people. (Welcome to the USA, home of the conspiracy theory – and since I was living in San Francisco at the time, any sort of paranoiac anti-establishment theory had fertile ground to prosper.) This is what this reminded me of, how scared people will leap at any explanation for the inexplicable.My other thought is similar to many others’: why was the blindness white instead of black? We think of blindness as everything going black, the total lack of sight information to the brain. I think it’s an allegory on today’s society because in the past, we were often blind to the everyday world because information didn’t reach us but now EVERYTHING reaches us and it can be like a giant beam shone in our face where we can’t distinguish between all the information we receive. Mushrooms in the dark being fed bullshit to a world of information overkill. Only a thought.Obviously a book I’d recommend, if you can get past imagining a world wallowing in excrement because the sanitation system has also broken down – but that’s “not seeing the forest for the trees” because there are more important points to be considered here, and to spark debate. Sisi is at a dead end where she lives because although she has a university degree, no one will hire her. Her boyfriend is in a dead-end teaching job, her father in a dead-end civil service job, and she can see that neither she nor anyone else will ever achieve what they’ve dreamed of, so when she’s offered a job as a “nanny” in Belgium, she leaps at it. Byatt, who won the Booker Prize with the excelMargaret Drabble has the misfortune of not only being the sister of an even more acclaimed author, A.S. Byatt, who won the Booker Prize with the excellent “Possession” – and with whom she has a distant relationship – but also of being a feminist ahead of her time but not far enough ahead of her time to be “rescued”. The reason I say “ahead of her time” is that when she wrote this, in 1965, feminist novels were mostly in their infancy and soon tended to be more strident (in my opinion), victimizing women and heaping all the blame on men and a male-dominated society. (I won’t deny that these accusations were mostly true…) Drabble’s feminism is more in tune with the mood today of self-empowerment, which owes a lot to those feminists of earlier days; while men could be seen as the oppressors back then, in this book they become irrelevant to a woman’s self-determination. (I am sure that many women will disagree with my assessment but I’m sure that no one can dispute that a lot has changed in 60 years; “you’ve come a long way, baby”, since Virginia Slims sold you a more feminine form of cancer!)The protagonist, Rosamund, a Cambridge graduate writing her thesis, has an accidental encounter with a BBC newsreader which results in her becoming pregnant. Before this, she never gave much attention to anything out of her academic field, 18th-century (or 19th, I can’t remember) English poetry; she had her chaste flirtations but protected herself by convincing each that she was involved with another man of their acquaintance, and never really thought about an after-thesis life. However, her pregnancy changes that and forces her to make some determinations. One thing that protects her is that she is from a privileged situation so money is not a consideration; obviously whether in that time or this time, empowerment requires financing. She has the economic freedom to visit the library to research and write her thesis but in spite of this liberty, she still has to live in a society where single motherhood was not looked on well, especially in her economic class; everyone expects that she’ll either visit a doctor to have a procedure to “eliminate the problem” or at the least give the baby up for adoption. A lot of strong hints and expectations are thrown her way but she is either oblivious or impervious to all the voices around her. The baby is hers and so is her life. This leads to a nail-biting final chapter. (I read this book with my wife, who loved it as much as I did, in spite of the nail situation.)This book is not all drama, although there are some things that affected me greatly; it’s more amusing as Rosamund wades further and further into taking charge of her life, and that of her baby. Everything is cast in a humorous light, from maternity to the National Health Service to the indifference and/or raised eyebrows of her acquaintances, one of whom, Lydia, sees a particular advantage for herself in all this while being a tremendous help. (According to Wikipedia, it was also adapted into a 1969 film, something I didn’t know: in the UK, “A Touch of Love”, in the USA, “Thank You Very Much.”) I really liked this book and look forward to reading more as I have a fondness for British women writers from this time, for reasons even I can’t explain. Julian BarnOne of the reasons that I love Czech literature is that it poses very human problems and dilemmas but doesn’t necessarily offer solutions. Julian Barnes wrote, “Books are where things are explained to you. Life is where things aren’t.” In my case, I like happy endings but life isn’t usually like this; we often just get over and get on with it. It might be appropriate to start this  off by saying, “Physician, heal thyself,” (or in this case, “preacher”) but I’ve always thought that applied to hypocrites and the pastor here isn’t that; rather, he’s troubled by preaching the Gospel when it’s something he isn’t living by. Daniel Vedra is the pastor here who ministers to his flock, trying to guide them through the confusions of post-Communist Czechoslovakia while being a good husband to Hana and good father to his three children, two with Hana and one, Eva, from his previous ill-fated marriage, which still haunts him. The marriage haunts him because it only lasted four years, three good and one in which his wife, Jitka, is dying from cancer, and as is not uncommon, he’s raised his dead wife to something like sainthood, an ideal that neither Hana nor Eva nor any other woman could possibly match up to. Hana is a good woman but she’s not Jitka.There are four principal characters who narrate the story: Daniel, Hana, his lover, Bára, and his lover’s husband, Sam; Daniel carries Jitka over his heart like a medallion, Hana had only had bad experiences with men, Bára has a son, disdained by Sam, from her previous unhappy marriage and Sam has been married twice before, the last broken up for Bára. So, everyone is carrying more than enough baggage into this unholy mess and while Daniel and Bára have the common ground of the love they’d both been waiting for, Hana and Bára have the common ground of being less than their husbands desire; in short, all of more in common than they perhaps realize. And so it plays out with Daniel carrying out an adulterous affair while preaching from the Bible and displaying Jesus’s example of forgiveness by mentoring a released juvenile offender and welcoming him into his home, where he meets Daniel’s daughter, Bára trying to convince Sam of her love while carrying on an affair, Sam simultaneously demanding and rejecting Bára’s love… If it sounds like a Peyton Place, it’s not, it’s only humans trying to attain the impossibly complicated goals they set for themselves and all this with beautifully poetic prose – which was my problem here. review: This book had been on my list even before Gurnah won the Nobel Prize so I wasn’t one of those scrambling to find out who the author was when it was anThis book had been on my list even before Gurnah won the Nobel Prize so I wasn’t one of those scrambling to find out who the author was when it was announced; this is not a boast but more due to my passion for lists of prize nominees, and this book was nominated for a Booker one year. Nonetheless, I was never pushed to read it until it became part of a book discussion group which I’m in with my wife. A rare but welcome opportunity for us to read something together, especially since we love to bounce impressions of films and books off each other.There are many books which are modeled off Biblical tales but this is a story mirrored off the Koran, something which turned off many readers unfamiliar with Islam’s Holy Book, but this wasn’t a problem for me since many of the stories are similar. The protagonist is Yusef and his story parallels that of the Yusef in the Koran, which is widely quoted in the novel. As a small boy, he lives a happy existence in his family in Tanzania before the first World War, particularly looking forward to visits from his Uncle Aziz, who always rewards him with a coin at the end of his visits; I think that most of us can identify with this, visits from relatives who gave us small gifts. However, Aziz is not really his uncle but a businessman who has lent money to Yusef’s father and when his father can’t pay, Yusef is taken in payment of the debt, to work it off in his “uncle’s” store; basically, he is sold off into slavery, something not uncommon in East Africa, particularly among the Arabs. All this develops slowly, as well as Yusef’s realization that he is not off on a family visit to learn the business and that the situation may be irreversible and final – and that he’s not the only one in this situation, where children are commonly used as security, functioning as slave workers or concubines. Children are routinely snatched off the street in broad daylight and public torture not only can take place at a moment’s notice but are public spectacles for bystanders to cheer on. Aziz’s god-like stature also takes a beating as he is proved not to be infallible and, out of his own environment, just as prey to the vagaries of other local leaders. Meanwhile, through this all, there are rumors of the Europeans arriving – in this case, the Germans – who will soon put an end to all this savagery and put order into this part of the world.One of the interesting things about this book is that it’s written by an African who puts the lie to the story that all was harmony and peace before the Europeans arrived. It was a world where cruelty and brutality ruled over compassion and kindness, and if your life was not predestined then it was at least up for sale; slavery is slavery and a slave’s life is not his or her own, and nothing has any value except force and power. In an interview, Gurnah also pointed out that Zanzibar’s and Tanzania’s independence in 1964, when he was a teenager, also brought brutal civil war, similar to what took place in Rwanda. It became open season on ethnic Arabs and Indians and he told the story of how a man ran into a mosque with a shotgun and shot everyone inside, including children. He said that nothing was ever done about it; it was as if nothing had happened. One point of this and of the book is maybe that while colonialism brought exploitation of resources, violence and human exploitation was already there. I liked this book – “enjoyed” isn’t the word I’d use with such an inhuman situation – because while it mirrors the story from the Koran, as I understand the story, it also deals with the hopelessness of Yusef and others in his situation and how each confronts it, knowing that their life has been decided by others. review: With all the “serious” reading I do, I realize that sometimes I just need a “feel-good” novel, where the good guys are good, the villains are bad, andWith all the “serious” reading I do, I realize that sometimes I just need a “feel-good” novel, where the good guys are good, the villains are bad, and it all works out in the end. Patricia Wood’s premier novel, “Lottery”, was shortlisted for the 2008 Orange Prize and while it wasn’t my favorite of the runners-up, I like it a lot better than the winner, Rose Tremain’s “The Road Home.”The narrator, Perry Crandall, starts out by reminding us that he’s not retarded because you have to have an I.Q. below 75, or in some cases 70, for that and he has 76. He’s just slow – or as his Gram says, the rest of the world is just too fast, something I’m inclined to agree with at times! – but he’s as good-hearted a person as you can meet. (There’s a tendency here to compare Perry with Forrest Gump but the storylines are nowhere similar.) Perry was abandoned by his mother (boo, hiss!) and left with her in-laws. (The whereabouts of Perry’s father are unclear at first but his story gets filled in.) His grandparents are a model for raising a mentally-challenged child as they support him, never telling him he can’t do something, just telling him it takes more time, and Perry not only learns to be a crack sailor from his Gramps, but auto-sufficient thanks to his Gram who won’t stand for laziness or excuses. After the grandfather dies, Perry and his Gram live pinching pennies, without the support of his “cousin-brothers” (double boo, hiss!) who not only won’t give them a dime to help out but barely maintain any contact. The two live a life of weekly bingo nights and lottery tickets. Perry works in a boating supply store for Gary, along with his best friend, Keith, a flatulent Vietnam vet, visits Cherry, the slightly oversized clerk at the convenience store. These are our good guys. (Yea!)Then come two dramatic changes. First, Gram dies and his siblings and Mother argue about who’s going to be stuck with Perry, as well as how to get him to sign over his share of the house, which they promptly sell out from under him and give him his “share” - $500. Since none of them want him, he is forced to live in a small apartment over the shop. The second thing that happens is that Perry wins $12 million dollars in the lottery and as can be imagined, everyone who’s ignored him before suddenly takes a great interest in his welfare, particularly his heretofore mostly absent brothers and mother. As expected, there is the sweet talk but as this really goes against their natures, this is quickly followed by more forceful actions, as they are desperate for the money. The younger of the two brothers is a milquetoast with his lawyer wife barking up his ass, the mother may be more accustomed to earning a living lying on her back, and the oldest is on his fifth wife with legal and illegal financial problems; the acorn doesn’t fall far from the tree, as we find out. (No spoiler here as most of this is either on the book cover or easily predictable.)All of this plays out with tragedy and happiness with a good deal of humor packed in, especially as Perry may know right from wrong but is still a bit of an innocent and we’re with his friends, all screaming from the sidelines about what he should and shouldn’t do. The ending was not exactly as I expected but plausible, especially since in my reader’s heart, I knew it wouldn’t end badly; a few scraped knees but a happy ending nonetheless....more

review: Well, this is a strange and horrifying, but delightful thriller. Kenji is a Tokyo tourist guide who has an American client, Frank, who he suspects of Well, this is a strange and horrifying, but delightful thriller. Kenji is a Tokyo tourist guide who has an American client, Frank, who he suspects of being a brutal serial killer. (Think Black Dahlia.) This is not exactly a cat-and-mouse story but a story about how he reacts in those circumstances. And maybe how we’d react to having a possible vicious murderer at our side, and guiding him around. It develops into a sort of Stockholm Syndrome situation; Kenji can’t quit, especially when he receives a gruesome “message” at his doorstep that “someone” knows where he lives. He confesses his suspicions to his high-school girlfriend while fearing that she could be the next victim with one wrong move.The book can be divided into two parts in a sense: the first half when Kenji can’t believe it can be true (while the reader is thinking, oh yes, it can) leading up to a splatter-horror segment (shout-out to Judith Sonnet) and the aftermath, which forms the second part and the Stockholm Syndrome really kicks in; how do you escape your situation without becoming further involved and/or putting a loved one in danger as well. Not a book for the sensitive.The book brought back two memories for me. One is Ann Rule’s book, “The Stranger Beside Me” which is about her working on team to trace a serial killer in Washington and one of her colleagues is… Ted Bundy, who was the killer, of course! The other was when I lived in New York and my upstairs neighbor was a disturbed Vietnam vet. He came down on New Year’s Eve to share his misery: his wife had told him she was leaving him. He had a weapon with him to, shall we say, persuade me to commiserate with him. A long evening. At one point, he asked how they were as neighbors and I said, fine, except that you know how kids are, his daughter (four or five years old) liked to run in the house and these apartments, you can hear everything (no mention of the arguments) and I laughed because it was just a normal thing for me, growing up with kids and kids run. His eyes opened wide, and he said, “I’ll kill her!”, and started to get up; I assured him it didn’t really bother me, you know how kids are, and calmed him down. That was my New Year’s Eve. So, I could identify with Kenji, just trying to calm Frank down whenever Frank had a “look” in his eyes, not point out inconsistencies in his background stories, and just get out alive.This was a taste of Japanese thrillers I’d never had before, which can be aa lot stronger than the Western ones I’m used to, much grittier suspense. I’d had a brief encounter with this in a book by the other Murakami, who’s not related. (An episode in “The Wind-Up Bird” with a Russian.) I’d recommend this book but with the caveat that it may not be to everyone’s taste. You’ve been warned....more

Burroughs, although some cited “Blade Runner”) as the pThis isn’t so much a novel with a plot as John Coltrane riffs on Bukowski (or maybe William S. Burroughs, although some cited “Blade Runner”) as the plot takes second place to language and its use to create shifting moods and momentum. The writer is a renowned Congolese poet with a strong appreciation of jazz and African rap; this could have easily made the book unreadable and nonsensical but like all music, if you can melt into the beat, the rhythm, you can flow with it. To explain, there are various lines repeated, like refrains or passages, many times in the book which can make you crazy as a literary device but make perfect sense if you see it as music or poetry. It’s also very cynical about Africa and the American / European colonialization and exploitation of minerals and people.The story centers around the reuniting of two friends and their different perceptions of the unnamed country of their birth. (Neither of the two Congos is mentioned specifically although Zaire is.) Requiem is the one who stayed behind and has become a sort of wheeler-dealer who knows the terrain very well and how to exploit all parties, from the leader to the Europeans to the natives. Lucien is a writer who has returned from living in Europe and has high-minded ideas which in no way correspond to the reality of the country. There are the Europeans (or “tourists”), the university students with their Marxist pretensions and protests, the miners who have no patience with the students (and vice-versa) although they are all in the same boat together, and the women, aged from pre-pubescent to 41 (when they stop counting), who are all prostitutes advertising and selling their services because what else can they do to survive? All parties meet in Tram 83, the club where everything happens because it’s really the only place in the city to meet, even when there’s no room inside. All revolves around diamonds (“the stone”) because it’s why the Europeans are there and what everyone is connected to as the source of all money. The relationship between Requiem and Lucien changes as pragmatism clashes with idealism.This is not a book for a casual reader but rather a book for someone looking for something different. If the men are all mercenary and the women all prostitutes, it is from necessity because life with “the stone” has left them no alternative now that the West has stripped everything else away and left them with no other way to survive. However, the book has a lot of humor to it if you can see past the dismal setting and form of life. If Bukowski or Burroughs left a bad taste in your mouth or you just can’t get past that form of sexual bluntness and cynicism, this isn’t your book. This isn’t a book just to read, it’s a book to dance with or maybe just snap your fingers....more

review: Reading some of the s on Good Reads, there were many who were either perplexed by this novel or plain just didn’t like it. They are absolutely jReading some of the s on Good Reads, there were many who were either perplexed by this novel or plain just didn’t like it. They are absolutely justified in feeling this way because if a book is placed in the American West in the 1800’s, you have certain expectations. If you reading about an immigrant coming to the USA with nothing but a dream, you have expectations. Well, so did Håkan, Swedish immigrant and protagonist of the story but both they and he find out that things aren’t what they ought to be.The first problem here is that the author, Hernán Díaz, was born in Argentina but moved to Sweden as an exile as a child, where he grew up, so his influences are not only North American. He has admitted that the story was greatly influenced by the Argentinian stories of the Pampas – think of these as South American westerns - as much as anything else. (For a sample, you might look at the epic poem by José Hernández, “The Gaucho Martín Fierro.” I also ed another story, “The Clouds” by Juan José Saer, which I liked very much.) So, he doesn’t follow the stereotypical American western nor the stereotypical immigrant-comes-to-America-and-finds-happiness-and success story that we’re used to. Finally, there is something which bugged the shit out of many readers, including me, but has an explanation.The story is of Håkan, who grows up with his older brother on a farm in Sweden. His brother enchants Håkan with travel stories and when it’s clear that there is no real future for them on the farm, they take off for America, via England. However, the two brothers are somehow separated on the English dock and the only English word that Håkan knows is “America.” This lands him on a ship but instead of being headed for New York, his brother’s destination, his ship is headed is headed for San Francisco. Once he realizes his error, the mission in Håkan’s mind is to travel to New York and look for his brother, not having any ideas of how big the USA is nor, being a farm boy, how impossible it is to find someone in a big city when you haven’t a clue of what exactly IS a big city or where they might be. (San Francisco was just beginning to be affected by gold fever at the time.) There are more misadventures than anything else and while he meets some good people, he meets far more scoundrels, villains and just bizarre individuals than can be believed, all hampered by his poor English, to the point where humans are more a curse to him than anything else. This forms the circle of his life: wandering and avoiding people, then trusting them to his own misfortune, then avoiding them once again. This circular pattern turns out to be the part that bugged people because some passages of the book seem to repeat, to the extent that you wonder if it’s a printers’ error because you could SWEAR you’d just read the same thing 10-15 pages back – except that there are very slight changes. This reflects the circularity and routine of Håkan´s life, an almost pointless existence.I read this with my wife and while I liked it and recognized what Díaz was trying to do, my wife just found it depressing, and boring in parts. I can’t disagree but this alternate vision of historical fiction and the poetry – again, I’ll mention Martín Fierro – is probably why it was shortlisted for the Pulitzer. (His next book, “Trust”, was a co-winner.) It’s not a book for anyone, especially if you enter with a specific vision of what a Western, coming-to-America book should be – because it’s not that. review: This book has been ed by so many people and much more eloquently than I could but I’d like to weigh in with my own thoughts, at least, even if tThis book has been ed by so many people and much more eloquently than I could but I’d like to weigh in with my own thoughts, at least, even if they won’t be particularly original.This was a beautiful but heartbreaking book. It’s also one of the few that I read simultaneously with my wife and she felt the same way. Coincidentally, we also saw a film or show which had a similar storyline (and whose title I can’t remember just now) but with a protagonist that was less endearing than Shuggie so that served as a good contrast. It’s hard to pick a particular theme to focus on but I’ll choose two. The first is the devastating effect that alcoholism can have on a family, destroying them from within and ostracizing them from without. (Even if those that ostracize have nothing to be proud of themselves.) Shuggie’s mother, Agnes, falls deeper and deeper and just when you think she’s touched bottom, she falls a bit further. One by one, the family drops away until it’s only Shuggie to take care of her, and even he knows in his heart that it’s hopeless. He knows that he can no longer save her, so doesn’t try. The book also shows the myth that alcoholics can just stop any time they want when Agnes manages to stop but is pushed off the wagon unwittingly by the man who helped save her. The book shows what anyone who’s lived with an addict knows: they are the ones who have to save themselves.The second theme is the difficulty of growing up gay in an overtly macho society; not only is Shuggie bullied but his father more-or-less abandons him, and his brother is embarrassed by him. (When his father suddenly takes an interest in him again, we see what Agnes is capable of as a fighter, definitely a force to be reckoned with!) In a sense, Agnes and Shuggie are co-dependents, fiercely defending each other on their island; they love each other, support each other, but ultimately can’t help each other.I was interested to read how the book went over with critics in Glasgow and the answer was, not very well. Some expressed they were tired of reading books about negative aspects of the city, poverty, drugs, crime and housing estates, but another that I read said, basically, it is what it is. Not all of these are in this book but the picture painted is bleak enough. The residents have been hit hard by Thatcherism and hope is scarce and this was also a theme, in my opinion, making the characters mean and mercenary. He and his friends only dream of escaping their tiny Georgia town and enlisting for Korea is their chance.The first four parts are a flashback accompanied by a character study, of Frank, Cee, the lover Frank leaves behind when he returns to Georgia to rescue Cee, and the grandmother; the lover is barely referred to afterwards and the grandmother only as an example of someone who felt she was better than everyone else because of her money but learns something about community, as do Frank and Cee. review: Anyone who has read Ann Patchett’s memoir of how she became a writer, “The Getaway Car”, knows about this, her first novel. She was waiting tables andAnyone who has read Ann Patchett’s memoir of how she became a writer, “The Getaway Car”, knows about this, her first novel. She was waiting tables and while she worked, she was writing her first novel in her head with the intention of putting it to paper when she got home at night. Of course, anyone who had ever done this kind of job knows you’re too exhausted to do much of anything when you get home so the novel didn’t quite arrive to its eventual publication so easily but that’s all in her memoir. (In fact, a lot of her novels are rewrites of her memoirs – “Commonwealth”, for example.)This novel didn’t quite work for me, for all its polishing, because most of the characters didn’t work for me. It has all the marks of a first novel, beautiful writing at times and partially-developed characters mixed with a lot of plot-stretching; that is to say, it’s hard to say what motivates the principal actors to do what they do or act in ways that seem to be inexplicable, and she doesn’t bother to justify it either. I felt the presence of a lot of plotlines which painted her in a corner with no way out so she ignored them.She described this as a choral novel, which it is in a sense, but one where one character picks up where another leaves off. We start with Rose, a young woman adrift in her San Diego-area beach town with a stunningly-beautiful mother (much like Ann’s). Rose doesn’t quite know what she wants so she marries the man who has been mooning after her for years at church, a teacher who teaches her to drive. This is the key to Rose’s freedom as she only wants to drive around all day, sometimes taking trips so far that she doesn’t arrive home to make dinner. When she becomes pregnant, she decides to leave him, take the car and drive cross-country to a Catholic home for unwed mothers in Kentucky to have her baby there. She also takes over the cooking, replacing an aging nun (much like Ann’s favorite nun.) A lot of Rose’s character is amorphous; she either cannot or chooses not to explain herself. She chooses not to give up her baby and marries again without divorcing her first husband and if her first husband is the weakest, most over-indulgent milquetoast ever, her second husband is not far behind. And so it goes, he picks up the story and part three is the daughter finishing it up.I had several problems with this novel but the biggest was a problem all-too-common in literature which is when a writer tries to get into the head of a character of the opposite gender; if Ann Patchett thought that this is how men think and act, I beg to differ because these men accepted EVERYTHING without the least intention to protest, just whine a little (but not too loud, lest Rose take it badly.) Rose isn’t a violent and morose woman, she’s just unknowable, even to herself apparently, cold and selfish, and they choose to worship her rather than question her. This is in a sense the second problem: Rose is never explained so after the first part, we have absolutely no idea what’s in her head and why she seems so furious and intolerant with the world. (Apparently Ann liked her though because she appears in a later novel, “Run”, as a cook.) In the third part, the daughter spends a lot of time and feels a lot of anguish trying to connect to her mother who seems totally unconnected to her, to the point of leaving her to others to raise. (The details of all this are what makes the novel so this isn’t really a plot-spoiler but a reflection.) Rose is the unknowable center of this novel but it was an unsatisfactory mystery for me. In a sense, she feels like the female embodiment of the man who’s always taking off because he can’t commit to anyone or anything so indulges his own urge to move on without regard for anyone else. No responsibility, just leave the others to work things out. In the end, I couldn’t identify or even sympathize with any of them, except possibly the daughter. I only felt cheated.(Added January 2024: the state of Florida has blacklisted this book in schools and what better recommendation can you ask for? As Ann Patchett said, you'd think that a book where teenage girls give their babies up for adoption would be just the message they'd embrace but no - maybe it's because they haven't even read it?)...more

He was a career criminal from a troubled background who spent much of his youth and early adult years behind bars in California prisons, including San Quentin, and ended up trapped because even when he wanted to go straight, no one would give him a job. This was the theme of probably his best novel, “No Beast So Fierce”, the rights of which were bought by Dustin Hoffman and made into the film “Straight Time” – a critical success but not much at the box office. However, he was then able to make it as an author, screenwriter, consultant and actor in small parts.This is not his best book because although his strength in knowing the life as a small-time criminal shines, his awkwardness in sustained narratives, particularly pacing, shows. There are strong parts and weak parts in this book and it didn’t flow for me. The idea is nothing new, three long-time criminals are free and ready to give up their lives of crime forever – after one last big score. Thea character development is good and obviously he has no problem with the mind-set but a lot of this reads like a college or army reunion; they meet former fellow convicts and catch up on what others are doing. I saw Ian McEwan read this book before it was released, when he was in Chile for a symposium on climate change. We were all enthused. My balloon of enthusiasm has now been popped. The book's protagonist, Michael Beard, is in every part of the book; no other characters express their opinions or points-of-view, so you're stuck with Mike - but who is he? A short, fat, thoroughly egocentric serial philanderer, married five times, a glutton for food and alcohol and thief of intellectual property who will stop at literally nothing to advance himself or save himself the trouble of facing up to his messes and the messes he leaves for others, even if he has to frame them and send them to prison. "Dislikeable" doesn't even begin to describe him, nor does he fit into the category of "loveable rogue", he's just plain detestable.However, he serves a purpose as an allegory for all the talk about "saving the world from climate change" because while there are many who "talk the talk", there are few who are willing to make the necessary sacrifices. (Like taking public transport to climate change rallies and protests instead of driving, or recycling, or a dozen other things.) Michael Beard knows he has to change but finds it inconvenient, and he in fact admits that all the possibilities he has to make these changes will never happen because he doesn't want to give up anything. (McEwan says he was inspired on a trip to see the results of climate change when the "boot room" where gear was stored descended into utter chaos as people just grabbed whatever gear was convenient rather than look for their own.)There were some well-written comic scenes but most just dragged on and the ending was anti-climatic in the extreme, making an unsatisfactory reading experience even more so. They are visited there by a female photographer who has come to interview the now-dead member of the group, a legendary survivor of the 1922 Great Fire of Ontario. She tries to get a grip on their world, and that of two younger companions, pot growers, one of whom works in a forgotten hotel and the other who ferries the weed into the city for sale. Later, one of the younger men brings his elderly aunt who’s been unjustly confined to a mental institution since she was 16. (An example of what happened to women who didn’t conform.) Any other details would be a plot spoiler and since this is a short book, I wouldn’t want to give it ALL away but it’s beautiful.Why is it beautiful? What’s the point? This is a meditation on aging away from a society where you don’t fit in, an escape towards the “good death”, to exit the world on your own terms. All of them have been preparing and supporting each other in this. It’s also a book about second chances while you’re waiting for that moment; that is to say, it’s never too late for things to happen, for things to change, for eyes to be opened to new possibilities and opportunities when you thought you were just running out the string. Each of the characters finds himself in the next world, in Hell, and decides that all those horror stories are greatly overrated because they are enjoying some of the best moments of their lives, over and over, until it dawns on them that these moments had consequences that they’d rather forget; indeed, that’s just what they had done in life, ignoring the consequences of their rash or insensible actions. The torture isn’t physical or mental, like when someone reminds of some fun moment in your past but as the person repeats it, or the memory comes back, you realize your “fun” may have been less so for someone else and now your conscience won’t let you forget it. It all ended in tears and now it’s your turn to suffer. (An example that wasn’t in the book: the kid that you and your classmates laughed at; now that we’re older, we realize how hurtful that might have been but we’d rather not dwell on it. review: In the beginning, I didn’t know what to make of this book but it reminded me of Audrey Niffenegger’s “The Time Traveler’s Wife” because it had some ofIn the beginning, I didn’t know what to make of this book but it reminded me of Audrey Niffenegger’s “The Time Traveler’s Wife” because it had some of the same elements. The story here is of a man with an uncontrollable disorder which causes him to suddenly take off, with no apparent warning, on long walks which only end when he collapses from exhaustion. It’s left to his wife to retrieve him from wherever he’s ended up, at any hour day or night. There is no diagnosis, no explanation, let alone a cure, for whatever it is that causes him to do this. He’s a high-priced attorney in a powerful New York law firm and this will have its cost eventually but meanwhile, we have the image of this eminent attorney walking around the office with a backpack full of all the things he’ll need, such as warm clothing, water, and (if I remember) energy bars. Is it tragedy or comedy? Just like in the Niffenegger book, it’s the wife who suffers as much or more because she has to watch her husband deal with this disorder but is a prisoner to it as well. The couple here also has a teenage daughter, who’s caught in all the usual teenage traumas; she’s overweight and has a dad who’s weird in such an embarrassing way that it doesn’t even bear mentioning. She feels he could control this if he really wanted to; not like her with her weight, which is the real problem, but which she’d rather not discuss, either.The second half of the book is melancholic, poetic and sad; it deals really with the nature of love in a marriage and a family, in dealing with an illness that you can’t see or understand but tears at the fiber of these relationships and destroying lives, leaving this frustrating devastation. However, I couldn’t get a grip on the book, with its weird illness. However, after a month away, it began to occur to me; the book can be seen as an allegory. An illness that often the sufferer feels coming – in the book, he has a kit ready at home and they have a drill for when he “knows” it’s about to happen again – and which takes his family along as helpless bystanders, like watching a locomotive moving slowly towards them and no power to stop it. I began to think of mental illness or more specifically, clinical depression, where the sufferer passes through an episode, there’s no recurrence for months or years and they think it’s over and passed – but it’s not. In this sense, I think the book has clear parallels and combined with the elegant prose, it’s a sort of lament for the devastating effects of an illness that no one can really understand and that receives comments like, “You could control it if you really wanted to. You just need to snap out of it!” Like its victims are just attention-seekers.Ironically, I read this book while my wife was bed-ridden with COVID during my vacation from work – I followed a few days after – so I had a lot of time to think but the book’s impact didn’t really sink in. I was caught up by the style of a book I couldn’t get a handle on – and I may be completely wrong here – and worrying about my wife. I enjoyed a previous book by Jonathan Ferris, “And Then We Came to the End”, which could also be seen as devastation to a family unit, in that case an office and its co-workers. (Weird coincidence, maybe people found it pretentious and gimmicky because it was written in the first-person plural, a strange device – and I read “The Virgin Suicides” just after, which used the same device!) I’m not sure this book is for everybody and my own take may prejudice anyone else’s by giving them a preconception but it’s worth reading for the writing alone, and may be food for thought as well....more

review: It is almost impossible not to fall in love with the character of Sully because he’s the most good-hearted and irresistible loveable rogue as you’re lIt is almost impossible not to fall in love with the character of Sully because he’s the most good-hearted and irresistible loveable rogue as you’re likely to find in literature. He’s the man who always gets away with things by being just a little more clever than those who oppose him and the man whose always there for the women in his life but can’t be counted on to be something more serious or permanent. In this sequel to “Nobody´s Fool”, which was made into a film with Paul Newman, we find a Sully who is feeling the effects of age in a way that many of us with this same problem can easily identify with. His doctor has warned him that his heart could give out at any moment but he chooses to be willfully oblivious; for once in his life, he has something to fear, something he can’t “wise-guy” his way around in a swift maneuver. At 70, his body isn’t what it was and even his long-standing affair with Ruth, the café owner who he still helps out every morning, has come to a halt, mostly because it’s run out of steam. (Or at least Sully has.) Ruth is also facing up to many of the problems that come with time and now has her daughter and granddaughter living with her, the daughter whose violent ex-con ex-husband is coming to look for her to seek revenge; he put her in the hospital once and that may have not been enough for him. There are also Rub, Sully’s sidekick, who idolizes Sully but fears that Sully no longer feels the same affection for him; Doug Raymer whose wife was about to leave him before she fell down the steps on her way out the door and broke her neck, leaving him with an obsession to find out who it was she was on her way to meet and the certainty that he is a failure as police chief as well; Gus Moynihan whose wife has sadly slipped; and Carl Roebuck, the constructor whose slipshod projects (and slipshod life) are about to collapse around him; and other new characters who weren’t in the first book. review: Although not the most well-known of his novels, many consider this José Donoso´s best, an allegory of Chile’s dictatorship (although in my opinion it Although not the most well-known of his novels, many consider this José Donoso´s best, an allegory of Chile’s dictatorship (although in my opinion it could easily be used as a model for any totalitarian, class-conscious state.) Started some years before the coup d’état that brought Pinochet to power while Donoso was in self-exile in Spain, it was finished afterwards and thus changed as he wrote it – not through rewrites but plot development, meaning the story changed as Chile changed. There are some characters fairly obviously modeled after personalities of the time as he took obvious shots at the upper classes; for instance, a doctor who “descends” to treat the “savages” (local farmers and workers) and is subsequently locked up and punished, but escapes to lead a revolt, an obvious allusion to Salvador Allende. His treatment of the upper class (of which he himself was a part) is brutal.The story revolves around a family, made up of seven or so siblings plus spouses and 30-odd cousins, who retreats to a summer house every year. They have no contact with the local population except for one brother who trades with the locals. The locals mine gold in abysmal conditions which they sell for a meagre amount of money and goods and it’s this profit which sustains the family. None of the rest of the family has the least idea of what work or business is, they only entertain themselves with social gatherings in other months and various games and entertainments in the house. The gold is sold to Europeans of a vague nationality and here is another poke at these upper-class Chileans because while the Chileans consider that their wealth makes them the equals, the Europeans are unimpressed by a group of South Americans, seeing them as little different than the local population.Early on, the story gives a hint of what’s to come, with the doctor declared by them as insane, transported in a cage every summer from the city and kept tied up in a room. From there, we have stories of homosexuality, rape, incest, murder, cannibalism, as well as other acts too horrible to describe, all with the idea of “drawing a thick veil” around them; that is, these are not things that are talked about. (Donoso’s adopted daughter used this idea of the “túpido velo” as the title of her biography of her tormented father and autobiography of her tormented self; she later committed suicide.) Dirty laundry is not washed in public and their social status keeps them immune from scandal in their own minds.Later in the first half, the adults prepare for an outing, a daytrip for a picnic at a waterfall near the house, a place almost completely unknown to them as they would never dare venture from the grounds which are protected from the “savages” by a high fence of cast-iron spears. They bring along a quantity of servants but leave the children in the care of other servants and this is where the next fantasy kicks in because in the second half we find they've been gone for one day in their minds but one year in reality. I thought this was a bit out of the spirit of the book but key to what follows because they return to a completely changed world where chaos has broken loose and what evolves is open warfare between some members of the family and servants on one side and other family members and servants on the other, with results just as horrible as those in the first half. The mix between black humor and horror makes the two hard to distinguish. Understanding Chile helps in identifying references but it’s not necessary for enjoyment.What is necessary? A good translation as this was the worst I’ve ever seen; it seemed not to have been translated by a person but by Google Translate and anyone who’s used an online translator for work knows what that means. It was at times incomprehensible because of the differences in pronouns between English and Spanish. A short example: in Spanish, “su” can mean “his / her / its / their / you”, depending on the context. Similarly, it’s common to skip “he / she / it” and all other personal pronouns as they are reflected in the verb-form and context. So, a human sees the context and immediately uses the correct forms; Google Translate sees a sentence in Spanish, says “WTF” and you get some sort of mixed-gender sentence, with personal and possessive pronouns chosen at random. Furthermore, slang is beyond Google’s understanding so I had a sentence where the speaker kept interjecting “eggs” into every sentence; it took me a few moments to understand that the translator was reading “huevón” which translates literally into “big egg” but is an interjection meaning in this context, “man” or “guy”. review: Having lived in the Czech Republic, I have a special place in my heart for their writers. The most well-known of these (not counting Franz Kafka) is MHaving lived in the Czech Republic, I have a special place in my heart for their writers. The most well-known of these (not counting Franz Kafka) is Milan Kundera, largely known through the film adaption of “The Unbearable Lightness of Being” but there was also the 1966 Oscar-winning adaption of Bohumil Hrabal’s “Closely Watched Trains”; both authors are highly recommendable and if you want a taste of typical dark Czech humor, Kundera’s “The Farewell Party” or Hrabal’s “Too Close a Solitude” (especially for avid readers), “The Little Town Where Time Stood Still” or “I Served the King of England” will do nicely. I am also a big fan of Josef Škvorecký whose “The Republic of Whores” had me on the floor, but whose “The Bride of Texas” was an interesting historical novel about the role of Czechs in the American Civil War. (I didn’t much like the worldwide favorite “The Good Soldier Švejk”, probably due to the translation.) However, all of these are either dead or, in the case of Kundera, getting close. (He’s now a curmudgeon living in France who’s famous for being extremely rude to anyone who asks him for an interview or guidance.)There are living authors, too, that I can recommend such as Ivan Klima or Iva Pekárková and all of these post-WW2 writers share a common topic, life under Communism, ranging from oppression to forced dirty deals to life-goes-on-in-a-village. This book by Tomás Zmeškal is no exception and has the interesting distinction of being by the only black Czech writer. (This doesn’t come up in this book but in another of his books.) Before the war, Josef meets Květa at a lecture on the deciphering of cuneiforms by the Czech scholar Hrozný; he falls for her and to his surprise, she chooses him over his friend and rival for her affections. Later, during communism, he is arrested for unknown reasons and she is forced to call on this ex-suitor, who now has power, to improve her husband’s conditions and he demands a certain “payment” in return. The story is told through various points-of-view, not necessarily chronological, by Květa, Josef, their daughter and a close family friend and psychiatrist. There are some amusing moments, too; typical Czech absurdity involving the doctor and a would-be burglar, and a visit from a British relative who arrives for the first time in Czechoslovakia and tries to describe the country to his sister. (Of particular note, the Czech tradition of carp-killing at Christmas; yes, I was also stunned when I first saw it and, yes, I know it’s a part of other Eastern-European cultures, too.) However, the focus of the book is on the rupture caused by her trying to help his ten-year prison stay by consorting with his “enemy.” There are many things here which are very Czech, such as the cottage in the country which undergoes unlimited alterations. (I once saw a BBC architecture special which featured the designed adaptability of these cottages.) There is also Josef’s Kafkian attempt to seek some sort of justice through the post-communist bureaus who promised this as part of the “new” regime. Unlike the East Germans, the Czechs mostly destroyed the files of who implicated who since so many good people had been forced to cooperate. (“Do you have any information on something your neighbor allegedly said in conversation at the market? We know your son is an intelligent young man and we’d like to see him keep his place at the university and not have to work in the coal mines…”) The book is about the tragedy caused by the regime, the human cost at such a personal level, driving a wedge between two people in love and the collateral damage to the family who have to step around this breech.I felt that some storylines were left dangling or abruptly ended, giving the novel a patchwork feel at times but I liked it very much and would recommend it to anyone who’s looking to break out of Russian literature but see another view of Eastern Europe. Mixed into the narrative are excerpts of books and memories of the time, reporting not only the grand dinner the Lincolns had while Willie was upstairs suffering but many commentaries on Lincoln’s supposed attitude and behavior during this crisis, the ongoing war, his physical appearance and whatever else the sometimes sympathetic, sometimes malicious gossips of the time could come up with in his time of suffering. (There’s a saying in Spanish that when the tree falls, many people make firewood.) Lincoln’s decision to pursue the Civil War was not popular on all fronts since many couldn’t care less whether the South seceded or freeing slaves if it meant sacrificing their men so there may have been poetic justice for them in Lincoln’s own loss.The principal narrators are three, a printer, a closeted homosexual, and a minister, but Willie’s voice is also heard and through him, that of Lincoln. Amid this tragedy, there is a lot of humor because all the spirits who speak don’t quite accept that they are dead and ready for the great beyond; for this, they are in the bardo, the Tibetan / Buddhist stage between this life and the next, preparing for death. And in a comic turn, each is in the state that existed in their mind at the moment of death: the printer had lived with his frightened bride as brother and sister until she was ready and now that the moment was at last at hand, he was hit by a falling beam so he walks through this world in-between almost naked and proceeded by a tremendous engorged member; the repressed gay man had cut his wrists in despair but repented at the last moment, having decided he want to see, smell, feel, and sensually experience the world as it was and is thus a tentacle mass of ears, eyes, noses and hands whenever he becomes excited. Since all were interred in the same Georgetown cemetery, almost all the other members of this community are of a similar class, with the exception of those from “the other side of the fence”, a common grave which held lower-class whites as well as slaves. All of these constantly squabble, some in a vulgar manner, which adds comic relief to this otherwise sad tale. However, the biggest problem is that they haven’t accepted that they are dead and believe they are only in “sick-boxes”, not coffins, and that they can somehow return to terminate all unfinished business, while brooding over the fact that they’re mostly forgotten by those they’ve left behind, loved ones who’ve moved on with their lives.The form of the book is something I’ve never come across and might be off-putting to some because the story is told as a constant conversation between the community but mostly through that of the printer, the gay man and the minister, and varies between dialogue and commentary about what action there is. I found it almost impossible to constantly check who was speaking but it really didn’t matter since they were not all that different; however, the other characters were quite distinct and added a lot to the plot. The most touching parts for me were Lincoln’s reluctance to let go and his son’s frustration in trying to help; I think that almost everyone has had the same sensation with a recently-departed loved one that they are somehow there with you, that you could almost touch them just as they want to touch you, if only you both knew how until you realize that this separation is permanent. An incredible book.(One final note: I never use audiobooks and with so many voices, you’d think that the audiobook would be difficult to follow but I see from many people who did listen that this is not so. Just in case…)...more

review: Anyone picking this up as their first Vargas Llosa could be forgiven for wondering why he won the Nobel Prize for Literature; the reason is obviously Anyone picking this up as their first Vargas Llosa could be forgiven for wondering why he won the Nobel Prize for Literature; the reason is obviously that this late novel isn’t one of his best. The quality of his writing is different now, not as evocative as it was in the past, but his storytelling skills are as strong as ever. It’s a solid book even if it isn’t as good as some of his other works.In this book, Vargas Llosa returns to a story of Peruvian society and social class, a topic he always returns to in his current essays and journalism as well (and which his son, Álvaro, also writes about with great perception.) The novel concerns two apparently unconnected men (although a connection is revealed early on) who, unbeknownst to each other, are fighting heroically against two of the ills that plague contemporary Perú. The owner of a transport company in northern Perú is being shaken down for protection money, which he refuses to pay. He has risen from abject poverty to building a successful business and although many of his competitors and fellow businessmen pay as a cost of doing business, he refuses; his father counselled him many years ago to bow down to no one and in the story of how his father raised him, paying for his education through menial jobs, this mental rectitude and fortitude are formed.The parallel story revolves around a soon-to-be-retired insurance company executive in Lima who is involved in his boss´s scheme to avenge himself against his two wastrel twin sons who only wanted him dead when he suffered a near-fatal heart attack. Their father has spent a large amount of money in the past covering for their drug- and alcohol-fueled lifestyles, including paying off a rape victim, and now wants his revenge when he marries his maid. He knows that with his more than 80 years, they will try to have him declared incompetent but more than that, there’s the social disgrace of their father marrying a woman from a lower class with dark skin. (In South America, an indigenous, non-European complexion counts in many cases.) The father disappears on his honeymoon and the executive is left to face any number of violent threats and coercion from the twins but his loyalty doesn’t waver. (Not a spoiler since there’s never any doubt that it would.)Vargas Llosa has touched on themes of Peruvian (which can be amplified into South American) class society from the beginning – his first novel was “The Time of the Hero” which novelized his experience in military school, a rite of passage for many upper-class South American males - so the theme of the novel is no surprise. It’s the story of two discreet heroes who don’t look for attention but only want to do what’s right for everyone by staying true to their convictions. It’s certainly a solid, recommendable novel if you don’t enter looking for another “Feast of the Goats” or “War of the End of the World”. There is also a prominent role for Lituma, a police character from some of Vargas Llosa’s other novels, such as “The Green House”, “Who Killed Palomino Molero?” and the sequel, “Death in the Andes”. A book worth reading because even if Vargas Llosa isn’t at his best, his better than most others....more
