review: I’ll start by saying that ghost stories are not my favorites because they too easily fall into clichés, more often than not, and this was no exceptionI’ll start by saying that ghost stories are not my favorites because they too easily fall into clichés, more often than not, and this was no exception. However, if you’re a fan of the genre, this won’t disappoint; just like in police/detective novels or chick-lit rom-coms, you can forgive a lot if you just like that kind of reading. I expected a Nordic detective story so I just didn’t choose wisely. Let the nit-picking begin then.There are two storylines which obviously merge towards the end: three friends go to an island in northwestern Iceland which is now used as a summer retreat but is deserted in winter, with the purpose of renovating an old house in order to eventually convert it into a summer hotel. Supposedly, this is a hot prospect with a high demand which would lead any sensible person to ask why no one has bought and renovated this house before. (But we know, don’t we?) The other storyline involves a divorced doctor with a specialty in psychiatry who moves from Reykjavik in the south to the northwest because his son disappeared three years ago, accelerating the disintegration of his marriage. His ex-wife insists that their son comes to her in her dreams, which he dismisses as some psychosis due to their loss. (But we know better, of course.) This was actually the better storyline for me because it unfolded like a good mystery, lots of loose threads which eventually came together. The other storyline was almost laughably ridiculous though, sort of “Blair Witch Project” meets “Scooby-Doo” – it even had a cute dog. Of course, it’s the dog who continually senses the evil presence, growling at what appears to be an empty corner or thin air. (But we know better, don’t we?) This was just one of the many clichés. There’s the doubting man who dismisses it all as just everyone’s imagination (which of course usually means he’s signed his own death certificate), the frivolous woman who is basically useless as she panics at everything, and the sensible middle-ground woman (married to the man) whose attempts at logical explanations fall flat in her mind, the only mind we actually enter here. Their cell-phone batteries die simultaneously so no way to contact the mainland, they have forgotten to pack anything of use such as a first-aid kit or candles for an abandoned house with no electricity, not to mention not even wondering where the previous owner disappeared to or why no one else seems interested in fixing up a house in a prime location. It all oozes stupidity beyond belief as one mishap befalls them after another; you wonder what could happen next and then it happens and they’re even more helpless than ever.The book also suffered from mind-numbing predictability, and boring plot twists. Adultery, of all things, rears its ugly head towards the end, which in one storyline I caught on to about 20 pages and the other was the obvious explanation for some parts of one storyline since it was the only one. There was also an unbelievable quantity of coincidences as the doctor continually meets just the right person at just the right time to fill in a blank and keep the story advancing. (It was the cinematic equivalent of the investigation is seemingly at a dead end and just at that moment, the television is turned on and just at that moment there’s a special bulletin which leads the investigation onwards.) There’s a final coincidence which was totally unnecessary to the story as the author “jumped the shark” in an attempt to keep connecting things. And the ending… even worse.So, what was good here? Plotlines aside, the suspense still had me on the edge of my seat because the atmosphere was excellent if you don’t nitpick the rest. Finally, we learn (once again) that ghosts are restless souls who just want revenge and a decent Christian burial – which means, of course that there are no Jewish ghosts. (Dybbuks aside.) First of all, ghosts communicate their grievances monosyllabically and, growing up in a Jewish family, I can tell you that not only is no complaint is less than a Shakespearean monologue but a Jewish ghost would just be resigned to his or her fate. (“Listen, Mr. Big Shot Detective, if it’s not too much trouble, can you find the schlechte mensch that put me here? Oh, never mind, I know you’re busy, what am I, I’m only a corpse, I’ll just lie here and molder…”) And even solving the mystery won’t stop them haunting you. Trust me on this one.Anyway, if you like ghost stories, you’ll probably like this one and if not and are bothered by the details, there are other books than this one....more

The protagonist is an expert on one particular writer from this era, he wrote his thesis after seven years’ preparation and now realizes that this was probably the high point of his life. He grew up in a loveless home and this is reflected in his inability to love any of the women with whom he becomes involved; he’s not misogynist in the sense of having no respect for women as he has many female colleagues at the Sorbonne who he respects and with whom who he has social contact but he is incapable of any lasting feeling with any of his lovers, save one. These relations generally last a year but there is one former student who lingers in his mind and who he misses as a steady companion. They get together for his birthday and as a gift, she gives him a night of sex – one of two explicit and graphic scenes in the book, the other with a pair of call-girls – but they both know that there’s no going-back and she eventually leaves the country when a Muslim party wins the Presidential election. Much of the book is dedicated to how this comes about and the resulting changes in France, as well as how it affects (or benefits) the protagonist.Islam is portrayed in this novel not as religious but as geopolitical, in my opinion, which is to say that some tenets may be overlooked in order to make it more acceptable to a larger population. This is also reflected in how the Muslim party wins because they position themselves as the alternative to Marine LePen and co-opt the other parties through an offer of power-sharing; in the USA, we’re accustomed to a two-party system but in most of the rest of the world coalition governments are the norm and as always, politics makes for strange bedfellows. How this insinuates itself into all reaches of French society is a lesson in how this could happen in other countries. (In the USA, it could be seen when some Republicans jumped on the Trump bandwagon rather than be left out, but you can see it in other countries more clearly.) The protagonist is apathetic to everything: religion is irrelevant, his academic career is going nowhere and women are only a vessel for his libido but as the Muslim party’s triumph begins closing some doors but reopening them in their own fashion, he begins to re-evaluate things as cost-beneficial rather than ideological. (No problem since his ideology is mostly below the belt.)This book came out the same day as the Charlie Hebdo attack in France and attracted controversy, not least because Houellebecq thrives on controversy although he now claims he wants to be loved, or something like that. He has admitted to being something of an Islamophobic but has also said that Europe could benefit from being Islamist. (One of the goals of the party in the novel is to bring the Islamist countries into the European Union as well as convert the existing countries.) It was wildly successful but wildly controversial in expressing patriarchal ideas that can easily be seen as misogynist. (Lowering unemployment by keeping women at home and out of important positions by paying men much more, for example.) It is an entertaining book if you read it and follow the protagonist’s development, imaginable and thought-provoking as you see how easily a change like this could occur. However, you can also prepare yourself to possibly be offended by some parts. Still, worth it, I think....more

review: When my wife and I have read the same book, we usually discuss it – a situation not all that different I’m sure than other couples or groups of friendWhen my wife and I have read the same book, we usually discuss it – a situation not all that different I’m sure than other couples or groups of friends – and this frequently leads to other insights. In my case, halfway through, I wasn’t exactly overwhelmed with this book but when I discussed it with her, I saw what I’d missed just by listening to myself and connecting the dots. (She’s big on empathy and insights, I’m big on parallel structures and layers.) I’d found what I was looking for.This is a story of a retired professor, a widower and East German now living in a reunified Berlin who finds himself captivated by the news story of a group of African immigrants camped out in a central plaza, demanding some clarification of their status so that they can work. He visits them in their hostel and even begins teaching German to some of the advanced students while slowly becoming more and more involved on their lives. What annoyed me at first was that he didn’t seem much interested in what they’d suffered so much as what their lives had been before civil wars crashed down on them; it seemed incredibly insensitive to ask about the “before” with its dead or missing family members and focus on a life they could never recover. However, my experiences with Czech and German friends and my life as an expatriate as well as telling my wife why I was underwhelmed suddenly put it all into focus for me. As an “Ossi” (former East German), he also had an immigrant experience as he adjusted to a new life in the West but where he was welcomed as a long-lost brother, many Germans rejected these new immigrants, with sarcasm, jokes and in some cases overt racism. As an end-of-WW2 child, he also had a gap since few parents wished to discuss what had just come before – this from German friends but also from what Gunter Grass suffered when he wrote “The Tin Drum” – so he just skipped over the unpleasant parts because that’s how he was raised. Some horrors are too big to absorb if you weren’t there. (My Czech friends didn’t want to discuss life under communism either nor the roles that many had played in their small town in the previous regime, even if their suffering was relatively minor and closer to inconvenient than anything.) This was the connection I’d been missing. There is a sort of parallel story of as parallel life as well as he had a long-term mistress while he was married. He managed the two by an extreme sense of order – I found this very German too – where his lover could only call on certain days at certain hours and meet him at a particular café wearing his favorite outfit and always approaching from a designated direction – until she’d had enough of this rigidity. As befits all of us who reach a certain age, he reflects on his structured past and seems to look at his new friends who have a completely unstructured and uncertain life in a new way; control only works if you have the power but if you lose it… His friends from the former East Germany also had their lives disrupted and reacted in different ways, just as not all are as welcoming to his African friends.In the end, I liked this book more as I began to penetrate a bit more into the mind of the protagonist and empathize with someone who’d lost control in his past but was trying to help others regain theirs. review: (Film  added on at the end)Lib Wright, a nurse and disciple of Florence Nightingale, is sent to rural Ireland to observe an 11-year-old girl, An(Film  added on at the end)Lib Wright, a nurse and disciple of Florence Nightingale, is sent to rural Ireland to observe an 11-year-old girl, Anna, who, it is claimed, has been living without food for four months. She believes firmly that this is impossible and is determined to expose the fraud but is unprepared for a mid-18th century impoverished post-famine Ireland where superstition and religious fanaticism abound. In a sense, it recalls the quote from Karl Marx about religion being the opium of the people; here it’s all they have to live on, their only refuge when there’s no food, either. She shares the duties of observation with a nun who’s also a nurse and in shifts they watch to see that no one is secretly passing food to the girl.I found the book interesting because it starts out as a detective story in which everyone in the village is a suspect, although we learn early on that not only Lib suspects some sort of fraud involved. However, she is a stranger and the only non-Catholic so she is equally suspect and gets the wrong end of the stick more often than not due to her arrogance and ignorance of what makes this other world tick and arrogance eventually turns to desperation.In the end though, it was less a detective story than something else. For me the story is about religious fanaticism playing on the mind of an innocent girl and exploiting her for personal reasons, while simultaneously blaming her for what led her to this point. Anna’s case is not the only one, either, of a woman taking the blame in a chauvinist society; Lib’s status as a woman also denigrates we find as we see reactions to her efforts to save Anna and in what brought her to this point in her life. This comes out in the vaguely-drawn characters which represent the different faces of authority; they probably don't need to be filled out because these figures are always the same and present everywhere. Some developments were easy to anticipate while others needed time to come out. In the end, I gave this a "4" because it did feel so locked in and repetitive at times. Most readers know Emma Donoghue through "Room", but that seems to be a “stand-alone” in the author's work because it didn't deal with Ireland and its treatment of women (as for example did "Hood") but I'd need to read more of her books to say for sure. It’s not a great book but there are more than enough underlying themes to make it a lively subject for discussion. (My wife and I are playing our perceptions off of each other now as we prepare to see the film. Chilean director so it’s a must-see for us in the cinema before it gets squeezed down on Netflix.) I may edit this  as more things occur to me – or my wife points them out – but it’s worth reading, not only to form your own opinion, but for an historical perspective on the Ireland that so many were forced to abandon for other shores.(Post-film addendum: If you see the film before you read the book, I doubt you'll enjoy the book so much. The film changed some things, and not for the better. The book unfolds its secrets slowly, giving you a sense of the frustration that Lib, the protagonist, feels. However, in the film, not only is one of the secrets revealed ten minutes in, but Lib is made out to be a drug addict. Finally, there is sex in the film that was DEFINITELY not in the book; during the sex scene, I could see my wife waving her finger, "no, no, no..." This was a film, paced for a cinematic experience with additional stuff tossed in and the mystery removed, making it all predictable. Well, for starters by thinking this is a dog book, because it’s not. Susan Orleans is a writer, a journalist and an essayist; she is not necessarily a dog sycophant writing another version of “Marley and Me” or competing with C. Bruce Cameron with a book full of anecdotes. That would be confusing “Animal Farm” with Old McDonald. This is a book about a famous dog as an icon and this image of Rin Tin Tin came to dominate so many people’s lives for so many decades, some so obsessed that you’d want to move away from them on a park bench when they began to talk. It’s a fascinating story for people who are interested in the business and marketing side of Hollywood, in particular, how you take the image of a dog as a brand and keep it alive for decades, reinventing it as times change, and how it took over the life of so many people. There’s also the rivalry with those promoting other wonder dogs, such as Lassie – a bitter point as Rin Tin Tin was a real dog, rescued from the battlefields of France in World War I, not an invented one like Lassie – and keeping up with the changing tastes for cinema and television animals. So, if you like anecdotes about Hollywood, this is a good book, but if you want love stories about pets, look elsewhere....more

review: Well, this was certainly a disappointment. Margaret Atwood starts out with a good idea and an interesting first half but then resorts to a sort of amaWell, this was certainly a disappointment. Margaret Atwood starts out with a good idea and an interesting first half but then resorts to a sort of amateurish, juvenile silliness that goes on too long, like a script for a brainless date movie; it’s adult but doesn’t strive to be something worthy of her talents.The book starts with a routine literary apocalypse: the US economy has collapsed causing massive unemployment and repossessions of homes, leaving many people to live in their cars and live in fear of roaming bands bent on robbery, violence, rape, etc.; this is played for comic effect because our female narrator, Charmaine, is a blonde goody-two-shoes determined to see the positive in everything while her husband, Stan, is a resentful schmuck who feels like a defeated failure, especially compared to his younger brother, Conor, who is a marginal sometime criminal who has always somehow come out on top, especially in dealings with Stan. What little money that comes in is from Charmaine’s waitressing job at what used to be an intellectual coffee shop but is now a bar with one part occupied by a pair of prostitutes. These two offer Charmaine the possibility to earn a little more by turning a few tricks, the idea of which repels her as something she could never do and Stan would never accept but which inwardly titillates her. (This hidden side of our Barbie doll later comes into play.)Their luck apparently turns when there’s an opportunity to join a closed community where accommodations are shared with another unseen couple with whom they alternate, each living in a model home for one month followed by one month in an on-site prison. They must sign a lifetime contract to live there and will never be permitted to visit or communicate with the outside world again. With the state the world is in, prey to criminals and poverty, and the comforts being offered, who could resist? This is the comic dystopia which has many possibilities, such as comparisons to totalitarian states where all is controlled by unseen authorities who control all information and monitor all activities, with strong parallels in “1984” but does the book go there? In a sense it does but mixes in so much broad comedy that the joke is lost, or rather, buried in silliness. Think about Stepford Wives. Think about Marilyn sex robots. Think about gay Elvis impersonators. Think about reading some other book, if possible.My impression is that Margaret Atwood started with a good idea but didn’t know where to go with it. The only time I can remember something like this being pulled off successfully was in Woody Allen’s “Sleeper” and this is not even close to that level. Dystopia turned into sex comedy is a tough challenge and Margaret Atwood isn’t up to the job here. It’s not a difficult book to read but frustratingly silly, less food for thought than “Charmaine and Ted’s Excellent Adventure.” Not her best effort....more

A man wakes up in covered in blood in his blood-splattered bedroom and can’t remember anything that happened from the night before. As the scene slowly unfolds, he finds his mother at the foot of the stairs with her throat slashed. In the American version, he’ll slowly piece the events together and find the real killer as well as the motive behind the murder and why he’s possibly being framed – but this is not America and things are not so simple as all that. You like unreliable narrators? There are two, one speaking from beyond the grave. You want someone who’s clearly innocent of the crime which he’s apparently committed? Not here because no one is innocent – or at least it’s not at all clear who is and who isn’t, nor of what – and you have to reboot your brain at various points as more details come to light. This book is darker than dark and constantly challenged me because just when I began to figure things out, and I had all the cards almost laid out although there was still a piece missing, and then came another part of the puzzle and I had to reshuffle the deck. That’s the problem with unreliable narrators, you can never be sure where you are and this casts doubt on what should be obvious because you begin to doubt yourself and your own judgement. review: Now that J.D. Vance has been elected senator from Ohio, I thought I ought to write my  of this book and get it over with. First of all, as has bNow that J.D. Vance has been elected senator from Ohio, I thought I ought to write my  of this book and get it over with. First of all, as has been seen in the campaign, Vance is a self-aggrandizing hypocrite, if everything he says in this book reflects what he feels. I think what's most interesting is the number of "hillbillies" in GoodReads who have mostly rejected this book as misrepresenting or exploiting them. Fair enough, he's an investment banker or something like that and knows how to make a buck, or at least seize on an opportunity so let's not run ol' J.D. down.First of all, if the "hillbillies" generally, disliked this book, who was it aimed at? Those who aren't or who don't share a similar background. I can imagine a bunch of privileged cocktail party attendees who seized on this as proof of something - or maybe were surprised that there were poor whites who could put a sentence together and escape the level of "white trash" - and use this proof for their own purposes, which is that more money either is or isn't the answer. It doesn't really matter which because it's not their money that is or isn't being spent but it's a useful plank in whatever sociopolitical campaign they're using their hot air on. But as J.D. Vance points out in the book, it's not so simple, any more than the solution to inner-city crime is more police and longer prison sentences; it's necessary to change the mindset before anything else. He makes his case well.However, his case is not exceptional; although I wouldn't define myself as a "hillbilly," growing up in New York City under similar circumstances made all this feel familiar. In fact, I could easily go shot-for-shot with him on family history, and mine might actually be more colorful although I doubt it would sell as well. So, I have my doubts about his case being so unique because a lot of people escaped similar situations and his story does a disservice to those of us who made something of ourselves but feel some need to brag about it. He does make a good point though about family support and people you meet along the way being an important part of this; he didn't do it alone and few others did, either. It's very easy to sink down in the morass of dysfunctional families, alcoholics, drug addicts and other negatives but rather than paint himself as miraculous, he should point out that he's one of many. Still, if he did this, the book wouldn't sell and the cocktail party set wouldn't be interested. They would still treat as quaint rare birds but there would not be a lot of interest in the story anymore. There's another underlying theme that comes out here, and was better understood in the light of his senatorial campaign; we can't help who or what we are and make no apologies for it. He neatly detailed how the situation developed in these parts of the country. The failure of the various administrations of both political stripes to deal with it is no surprise because speeches are easier to deliver than solutions - or at least good solutions. In his campaign, his position was more-or-less "they call us racists but we are Americans", which ties into being a Trump protegé because who better to codify a message? (Trump also told West Virginia coal miners that they were going back to work so his hillbilly messaging is consistent at least.) Vance also made the claim that he was raised to fight back agao¿inst any insult but stood there grinning when Trump said, "This man wants my endorsement so bad he's kissing my ass." He had his eye on the prize.The book smacked of hypocrisy even before the campaign and the campaign only served to clarify it; it's not best-selling out-and-out lie like James Frey's "A Million Pieces" but it comes close in many ways. It's more like those books by ex-officials and politicians who want to "set the record straight" by putting themselves in the best possible light. What follows is something reminiscent of the London bombing in WW II; each plot twist may as well be preceded by a screaming whistle because you can easily see them coming and no red herring can deflect your sense of what’s to follow. The novel is set in late 60’s / early 70´s Wilson/Heath/Wilson England but this historical context is mostly wasted because Serena is only vaguely interested; the same with the internal turmoil of the miners’ strike and Northern Ireland, both of which serve as background but which are not gotten into. (Intellectualism stops at cultural footnotes and references; current events play only a small part, mostly to give some reason why the mission was planned in the first place.) Even the attempt at a final twist mostly fell flat for me because I’d already given up hope of something more by that time. Frankly, Serena Frome is no Bridget Jones, she just a voracious but non-discriminating reader. (At one point, she puts Jane Austen and Jacqueline Susann on equal footing, though she later recants.) Nevertheless, you finally board, strapped in only to have the captain announce that there will be another delay because there are 87 planes in line for the only runway as the others have been damaged due to excessive seagull guano or something but be patient, the flight attendants will be passing out extra bags of peanuts to compensate for this unanticipated problem. Luckily for you, your neighbor has brought along snapshots of EVERY vacation he or she has been on before and proceeds to show them to you, accompanied by family anecdotes such as when Uncle Lester fell out of the tree or Mom burned the cookies and the fire department arrived. Soon darkness falls, passengers are snoring and you finally come to the conclusion that this flight will NEVER EVER take off – much like this book. You’re in…The Twilight Zone!!!! Why do I say this? This book has a very thin plot – wafer thin – interspersed with Martin’s dreams – but then the plot mostly runs out and you’re left with all of his remaining phantasmagorical fantasies, like one of those books of unfeasible architectural projects. The setting of an emerging New York at the end of the 19th century is interesting but this is finally “The Winchester Mystery House Meets the Tower of Babel”, an endless and pointless exercise in writing. This was a train wreck disguised as a book, but not precisely for the reasons that some ers gave. The most obvious reason to dislike the book was for the quantity of incest, particularly father-daughter, but other forms of older man/underage girl attractions. Martin Amis is greatly influenced by Nabokov and follows the advice that actions must match the character in order to be true to the character; however, "Lolita" is a classic of a man led to his own downfall by this attraction while this takes a slightly different angle which I found to be less serious and in a way, more dangerous. I don't want to get into it but I didn't like it at all. If the books admirers want to justify it in a "you just don't get it" sort of way, I'm fine with not "getting it." This wasn't even the worst of it for me. There are four basic storylines here, all with their share of black humor but only one even remotely interesting. There's the ex-gangster, from a long line of gangsters, whose behavior changes after being hit on the head; there's the underendowed writer for a scandal rag; there's the mostly asexual King of England whose 15-year-old daughter is secretly photographed in the nude, plus the King's attendant, Brendan Urquhart-Gordon, called Bugger for his initials, who's infatuated with the Princess; and there's a doomed flight with a coffin bouncing around in the baggage hold and causing all sorts of damage. Of these, the first is mildly interesting and the rest I could have done without. Much of the dialogue was like overheard conversations where you're not in on the shorthand references in the conversation.
